title: 1 Kings Chapter 17 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Kings chapter 17 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Kings Chapter 17 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Kings Chapter 17.

questions.question: Who was Elijah, according to 1 Kings 17:1?
options: A Tishbite from Gilead
A prophet from Judah
A priest from Jerusalem
A king of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: A Tishbite from Gilead
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 17:1 describes Elijah as 'the Tishbite, who was of the inhabitants of Gilead.'

questions.question: What did Elijah declare would not happen during those years in 1 Kings 17:1?
options: There shall not be dew nor rain
The sun shall not shine
The rivers shall overflow
The crops shall grow abundantly
questions.correctAnswer: There shall not be dew nor rain
questions.explanation: Elijah declared in 1 Kings 17:1 that 'there shall not be dew nor rain these years, but according to my word.'

questions.question: Where was Elijah instructed to hide according to 1 Kings 17:3?
options: By the brook Cherith, before Jordan
In the city of Zarephath
On Mount Carmel
In the wilderness of Sinai
questions.correctAnswer: By the brook Cherith, before Jordan
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 17:3 commands Elijah to hide by the brook Cherith, which is before Jordan.

questions.question: According to 1 Kings 17:4, who was commanded to feed Elijah at the brook Cherith?
options: The ravens
The widow woman
The priests
The angels
questions.correctAnswer: The ravens
questions.explanation: God commanded the ravens to feed Elijah bread and flesh while he drank from the brook (1 Kings 17:4).

questions.question: What happened to the brook Cherith according to 1 Kings 17:7?
options: It dried up because there had been no rain in the land
It overflowed and flooded the area
It was filled with fish
It became a place of worship
questions.correctAnswer: It dried up because there had been no rain in the land
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 17:7 states that the brook dried up because there was no rain in the land.

questions.question: Where was Elijah told to go after the brook dried up, as stated in 1 Kings 17:9?
options: To Zarephath, which belongs to Zidon
To Jerusalem
Back to Gilead
To Mount Carmel
questions.correctAnswer: To Zarephath, which belongs to Zidon
questions.explanation: God instructed Elijah to go to Zarephath in Zidon where a widow would sustain him (1 Kings 17:9).

questions.question: What was the widow woman doing when Elijah met her in 1 Kings 17:10?
options: Gathering sticks
Drawing water from a well
Tending sheep
Cooking food
questions.correctAnswer: Gathering sticks
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 17:10 says the widow woman was gathering sticks when Elijah called to her.

questions.question: What did Elijah ask the widow woman to bring him first in 1 Kings 17:11?
options: A morsel of bread
A cup of water
A piece of meat
A jug of wine
questions.correctAnswer: A morsel of bread
questions.explanation: Elijah asked the widow to bring him a morsel of bread in her hand (1 Kings 17:11).

questions.question: What did the widow say she had left to eat in 1 Kings 17:12?
options: A handful of meal in a barrel and a little oil in a cruse
A loaf of bread and some fish
Some dried fruit and water
A small piece of bread and wine
questions.correctAnswer: A handful of meal in a barrel and a little oil in a cruse
questions.explanation: The widow explained she had only a handful of meal and a little oil before they would die (1 Kings 17:12).

questions.question: True or False: Elijah told the widow to fear not and that her meal and oil would not fail until the LORD sent rain (1 Kings 17:13-14).
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Elijah reassured the widow not to fear, promising the barrel of meal and cruse of oil would not waste until rain came (1 Kings 17:13-14).

questions.question: How did the widow and her household fare after following Elijah’s instructions (1 Kings 17:15-16)?
options: They ate many days and the meal and oil did not fail
They soon ran out of food and suffered
They moved to another city
They sold their belongings for food
questions.correctAnswer: They ate many days and the meal and oil did not fail
questions.explanation: The widow, Elijah, and her household ate many days; the barrel of meal and cruse of oil did not fail (1 Kings 17:15-16).

questions.question: What happened to the widow’s son in 1 Kings 17:17?
options: He fell sick and had no breath left in him
He was taken captive
He went to the fields to work
He left the house
questions.correctAnswer: He fell sick and had no breath left in him
questions.explanation: The son became very sick and died according to 1 Kings 17:17.

questions.question: True or False: The widow accused Elijah of coming to remind her of her sin and to kill her son (1 Kings 17:18).
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The widow said to Elijah, 'Art thou come unto me to call my sin to remembrance, and to slay my son?' (1 Kings 17:18).

questions.question: How many times did Elijah stretch himself upon the child and pray for his life (1 Kings 17:21)?
options: Three times
Once
Seven times
Five times
questions.correctAnswer: Three times
questions.explanation: Elijah stretched himself upon the child three times and prayed for his soul to return (1 Kings 17:21).

questions.question: Complete the verse from 1 Kings 17:24: 'Now by this I know that thou art a man of God, and that the word of the LORD in thy mouth is ______.'
options: truth
powerful
true
just
questions.correctAnswer: truth
questions.explanation: The widow said she knew Elijah was a man of God because 'the word of the LORD in thy mouth is truth' (1 Kings 17:24).

questions.question: True or False: Elijah prayed to the LORD and the soul of the widow’s son came back and he revived (1 Kings 17:22).
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The LORD heard Elijah’s prayer and the child revived (1 Kings 17:22).

medium.title: 1 Kings Chapter 17 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Kings Chapter 17 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on 1 Kings 17, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God during hardships?
options: God provides for His servants even in difficult times
Trials mean God has abandoned us
We should rely only on our own resources
God is indifferent to human suffering
questions.correctAnswer: God provides for His servants even in difficult times
questions.explanation: Elijah was fed by ravens and sustained by a widow during a drought, showing God's provision in trials (1 Kings 17:4-6, 9-16).

questions.question: How does the passage teach us about obedience to God's Word in everyday life?
options: Elijah obeyed God's commands without hesitation
Elijah questioned God's instructions repeatedly
Elijah chose his own path independent of God
Elijah delayed action until he understood everything
questions.correctAnswer: Elijah obeyed God's commands without hesitation
questions.explanation: Elijah immediately went to the brook Cherith and later to Zarephath as instructed by God, demonstrating prompt obedience (1 Kings 17:3-5, 9-10).

questions.question: When faced with scarcity, how did the widow at Zarephath demonstrate faith and generosity?
options: She shared her last meal with Elijah first
She kept all her food for herself and her son
She asked Elijah to leave her alone
She refused to help Elijah
questions.correctAnswer: She shared her last meal with Elijah first
questions.explanation: Despite having little, the widow obeyed Elijah's request to make him a cake first, showing faith and generosity (1 Kings 17:12-13).

questions.question: What lesson about God's faithfulness can we learn from the widow's meal and oil not running out?
options: God faithfully sustains those who trust Him
God only provides when we have plenty
God's blessings are limited and temporary
God expects us to provide for ourselves only
questions.correctAnswer: God faithfully sustains those who trust Him
questions.explanation: God promised and fulfilled that the meal and oil would not fail until rain came, showing His sustaining faithfulness (1 Kings 17:14-16).

questions.question: How does Elijah's prayer for the widow's son teach about perseverance in prayer during difficult times?
options: Elijah prayed repeatedly and trusted God's response
Elijah gave up after one prayer
Elijah tried to fix the problem without God
Elijah blamed the widow for her son's sickness
questions.correctAnswer: Elijah prayed repeatedly and trusted God's response
questions.explanation: Elijah stretched himself on the child three times and prayed persistently, demonstrating perseverance in prayer (1 Kings 17:20-21).

questions.question: What does the widow's response after her son was revived teach us about recognizing God's truth?
options: She acknowledged Elijah as a man of God and trusted God's word
She remained doubtful about Elijah's message
She blamed Elijah for her son's sickness
She ignored the miracle and left
questions.correctAnswer: She acknowledged Elijah as a man of God and trusted God's word
questions.explanation: The widow declared she now knew Elijah was a true man of God and that God's word was trustworthy (1 Kings 17:24).

questions.question: How does Elijah’s reliance on God's provision challenge believers in their work ethic and trust?
options: It shows that trusting God includes diligent obedience and reliance on His provision
It encourages neglecting responsibilities waiting for miracles
It suggests working alone without seeking God’s help
It teaches that self-sufficiency is the highest goal
questions.correctAnswer: It shows that trusting God includes diligent obedience and reliance on His provision
questions.explanation: Elijah obeyed God’s directions and trusted God to provide daily via ravens and a widow, exemplifying faithful work and trust (1 Kings 17:3-6, 9-16).

questions.question: True or False: Elijah doubted God's command to hide by the brook Cherith and sought another plan.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Elijah obeyed without hesitation and went to the brook as God commanded (1 Kings 17:3-5).

questions.question: True or False: The widow at Zarephath initially refused to help Elijah because she had no food.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Although she had little food and was preparing to die, she obeyed Elijah’s request and shared her meal (1 Kings 17:12-15).

questions.question: In 1 Kings 17, Elijah’s prayer for the widow’s son shows the importance of __________ in prayer.
options: perseverance
doubt
impatience
silence
questions.correctAnswer: perseverance
questions.explanation: Elijah prayed three times persistently for the child’s life to return, showing perseverance in prayer (1 Kings 17:20-21).

questions.question: How does Elijah's interaction with the widow teach us about hospitality and serving others in church life?
options: Welcoming and caring for others is an expression of God’s provision
Hospitality is not important in times of scarcity
Helping others should be avoided to conserve resources
Service is only for those with abundant wealth
questions.correctAnswer: Welcoming and caring for others is an expression of God’s provision
questions.explanation: Elijah stayed with the widow, and despite her need, she cared for him, illustrating mutual service and hospitality (1 Kings 17:8-15).

questions.question: What biblical virtue is shown by Elijah praying to God before reviving the widow’s son?
options: Dependence on God through prayer
Self-reliance without God
Ignoring God’s power
Using magic to heal
questions.correctAnswer: Dependence on God through prayer
questions.explanation: Elijah earnestly prayed to God asking for the child's life to return, showing dependence on God’s power (1 Kings 17:20-22).

questions.question: How does this chapter encourage parenting with biblical wisdom during hardship?
options: Trusting God’s care and seeking His help in crises
Ignoring God's involvement in family struggles
Relying solely on human efforts
Giving up hope when troubles come
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting God’s care and seeking His help in crises
questions.explanation: The widow turned to Elijah and God during her son's sickness, and Elijah prayed for God's intervention (1 Kings 17:17-23).

questions.question: How does Elijah’s experience show humility and contentment in trusting God's timing?
options: Elijah obeyed God's command to wait for rain after the drought
Elijah forced God to act immediately
Elijah complained about the drought
Elijah tried to end the drought by his own power
questions.correctAnswer: Elijah obeyed God's command to wait for rain after the drought
questions.explanation: Elijah waited in faith at the brook and with the widow until God sent rain, demonstrating humility and contentment in God's timing (1 Kings 17:1, 7, 14).

questions.question: What does the story of Elijah and the widow teach about honesty and integrity in daily life?
options: Honesty and faithfulness lead to God’s blessing
Dishonesty is acceptable if circumstances are hard
Integrity is not important during trials
Trusting God excuses careless behavior
questions.correctAnswer: Honesty and faithfulness lead to God’s blessing
questions.explanation: The widow honestly shared her limited resources with Elijah and was blessed by God’s provision (1 Kings 17:12-16).

hard.title: 1 Kings Chapter 17 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Kings Chapter 17.

questions.question: What was the significance of Elijah declaring no dew nor rain except by his word, and how does this reflect prophetic authority in ancient Israel?
options: It demonstrated Elijah's personal power independent of God
It showed the LORD's control over nature through the prophet's word
It was a common threat used by prophets to intimidate kings
It was a symbolic statement about spiritual drought only
questions.correctAnswer: It showed the LORD's control over nature through the prophet's word
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 17:1 emphasizes Elijah speaking 'as the LORD God of Israel liveth,' asserting divine authority over natural elements, a key theme for prophetic legitimacy in Israel.

questions.question: The brook Cherith, where Elijah was commanded to hide, can be seen as a typological precursor to which New Testament concept?
options: The wilderness temptation of Jesus
The baptismal waters symbolizing new life
Jesus as the living water
The manna provided in the desert
questions.correctAnswer: The wilderness temptation of Jesus
questions.explanation: Elijah's retreat to a remote brook (1 Kings 17:3-4) parallels Jesus' wilderness experience, both involving divine provision and testing in isolation.

questions.question: How do the ravens feeding Elijah illustrate cultural and theological motifs distinct to the ancient Near East?
options: Ravens were considered unclean, highlighting God's power over the impure
Ravens were sacred animals, symbolizing divine messengers
Ravens were common domestic pets providing food
Ravens were ritual animals used in temple sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: Ravens were considered unclean, highlighting God's power over the impure
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 17:6 shows ravens, typically unclean birds in Levitical law, used by God to provide, underscoring His sovereignty over all creation.

questions.question: What literary device is employed in 1 Kings 17:14 where the barrel of meal and cruse of oil do not fail, and what does it signify?
options: Foreshadowing of Israel's future abundance
Irony about the widow's dire situation
A covenantal promise of divine provision
Parable illustrating faithfulness
questions.correctAnswer: A covenantal promise of divine provision
questions.explanation: The ongoing supply (1 Kings 17:14) serves as a divine promise, highlighting God’s faithful provision amid famine, a motif recurring throughout Scripture.

questions.question: In the context of ancient Israelite hospitality customs, why is Elijah's request for water and bread from the widow significant?
options: It was a demand for payment for prophecy
It was an unusual request violating social norms
It was a test of the widow's faith and generosity
It was a formal ritual requirement before prophecy
questions.correctAnswer: It was a test of the widow's faith and generosity
questions.explanation: Elijah’s request (1 Kings 17:10-11) places the impoverished widow in a position to trust God’s provision, reflecting ancient values of hospitality and faith.

questions.question: How does the widow’s initial response about having only a handful of meal and little oil reflect historical realities of famine and poverty in the ancient Near East?
options: It exaggerates famine for dramatic effect
It accurately depicts scarcity during droughts
It shows ritual impurity requiring purification
It reflects a metaphor for spiritual emptiness
questions.correctAnswer: It accurately depicts scarcity during droughts
questions.explanation: Her response (1 Kings 17:12) realistically portrays famine conditions, emphasizing famine’s devastating impact on common people in that era.

questions.question: What theological theme is emphasized by Elijah’s raising of the widow’s son from death, and how does it connect to broader biblical resurrection motifs?
options: Judgment upon Israel for sin
God’s power over life and death
The futility of human effort
A prophecy of the Messiah’s suffering
questions.correctAnswer: God’s power over life and death
questions.explanation: The miraculous revival (1 Kings 17:21-22) prefigures New Testament resurrection themes, affirming God's sovereignty over mortality.

questions.question: Which Hebrew word in 1 Kings 17:1, often translated as 'liveth,' underscores the living and active nature of God in prophetic declaration?
options: Chayah (חיה)
Qadosh (קדוש)
Emet (אמת)
Shalom (שלום)
questions.correctAnswer: Chayah (חיה)
questions.explanation: 'Chayah' denotes 'to live' or 'living,' highlighting God's dynamic and enduring presence as affirmed by Elijah (1 Kings 17:1).

questions.question: The drought announced by Elijah is an example of what type of prophetic judgment commonly found in the Old Testament?
options: Exile
Natural disaster as divine punishment
Military defeat
Idolatry
questions.correctAnswer: Natural disaster as divine punishment
questions.explanation: The drought (1 Kings 17:1) serves as a divinely sanctioned calamity, a frequent method to call Israel back to covenant faithfulness.

questions.question: How does the structure of 1 Kings 17, moving from the brook Cherith to Zarephath, reflect a chiastic literary pattern emphasizing divine provision?
options: It moves from community to isolation and back
It contrasts foreign and native lands
It shows God providing first through nature, then through humans
It highlights Elijah’s increasing power
questions.correctAnswer: It shows God providing first through nature, then through humans
questions.explanation: The chapter’s progression (1 Kings 17:3-6 to 1 Kings 17:8-16) illustrates a chiasm where God's provision shifts from ravens (nature) to a widow (human agent).

questions.question: What is the significance of Elijah addressing Ahab 'before whom I stand' in verse 1, considering ancient Near Eastern royal court imagery?
options: It indicates Elijah's subservience to Ahab
It implies Elijah's role as a royal counselor before God
It denotes Elijah's presence in Ahab’s palace
It is a metaphor for Elijah’s moral superiority
questions.correctAnswer: It implies Elijah's role as a royal counselor before God
questions.explanation: The phrase (1 Kings 17:1) evokes imagery of a prophet standing in God’s presence as a royal advisor, legitimizing his message to Ahab.

questions.question: True or False: The widow's declaration 'As the LORD thy God liveth' in 1 Kings 17:12 shows her faith in Elijah’s God despite her desperate situation.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Her oath (1 Kings 17:12) confirms belief in the LORD, indicating faith even in adversity.

questions.question: What does the drying up of the brook Cherith symbolize in the larger narrative of Elijah’s prophetic mission?
options: The end of Elijah’s prophetic authority
A transition from isolation to active ministry
God’s abandonment of Elijah
A sign of Elijah’s failure
questions.correctAnswer: A transition from isolation to active ministry
questions.explanation: The brook drying up (1 Kings 17:7) signals a shift from passive waiting to direct engagement, moving Elijah to Zarephath for further divine mission.

questions.question: How does the woman’s final statement in verse 24 serve as a theological climax in the chapter’s narrative structure?
options: It rejects Elijah’s prophecy
It confirms Elijah’s role as a true man of God
It calls for a new covenant
It demands a miracle as proof
questions.correctAnswer: It confirms Elijah’s role as a true man of God
questions.explanation: Her declaration (1 Kings 17:24) affirms the prophetic legitimacy of Elijah and the truth of God’s word, completing the narrative arc of faith and divine power.

questions.question: The raising of the widow's son can be seen as a foreshadowing of which New Testament event?
options: Jesus raising Lazarus from the dead
The Pentecost
The Transfiguration
The Resurrection of Jesus
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus raising Lazarus from the dead
questions.explanation: Elijah's miracle (1 Kings 17:21-22) prefigures Jesus’ similar act in John 11, underscoring God's power to restore life.

questions.question: Why does Elijah pray three times over the child, and what does this reveal about ancient Israelite practices of intercession?
options: It demonstrates ritual repetition for emphasis
It was an accidental repetition
It was a form of magical incantation
It indicates Elijah doubted God’s power
questions.correctAnswer: It demonstrates ritual repetition for emphasis
questions.explanation: The thrice repetition (1 Kings 17:21) reflects a literary and religious motif emphasizing fervent, persistent prayer in Israelite tradition.

theological.title: 1 Kings Chapter 17 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Kings Chapter 17 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What theological truth is demonstrated by God's command through Elijah that there shall be no dew or rain until Elijah says so?
options: God's sovereign control over nature and history
God's indifference to human suffering
Elijah's personal power to control weather
The inevitability of drought in Israel
questions.correctAnswer: God's sovereign control over nature and history
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 17:1 shows God’s sovereignty over the natural world, a theme consistent with Psalm 135:6, Matthew 5:45, Romans 8:28, and Revelation 4:11, affirming that God governs all creation according to His will.

questions.question: Why was Elijah instructed to hide by the brook Cherith according to 1 Kings 17?
options: To be preserved by God through provision of ravens
To escape the king’s wrath by hiding in the desert
To prepare for a public confrontation with Ahab
To receive prophetic training from an angel
questions.correctAnswer: To be preserved by God through provision of ravens
questions.explanation: God preserves His prophet Elijah by supernatural provision, sending ravens to feed him (1 Kings 17:3-6). This echoes God's care for His servants seen in Psalm 91:11-12, Matthew 6:26, Luke 12:24, and Hebrews 13:5.

questions.question: What does the miraculous provision of meal and oil to the widow at Zarephath teach about God’s providence?
options: God sustains His people supernaturally in times of scarcity
Human effort is the primary source of provision
God tests faith through withholding resources
Provision is dependent on social status
questions.correctAnswer: God sustains His people supernaturally in times of scarcity
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 17:13-16 reveals God’s sustaining providence, a theme echoed in Exodus 16:4, Deuteronomy 8:3, Philippians 4:19, and Matthew 6:31-33, showing God’s faithfulness to supply needs beyond human means.

questions.question: The widow’s initial response to Elijah’s request for bread shows what about human faith in God’s promise?
options: Faith often begins with scarcity and doubt but can be obedient
Faith requires visible abundance before obedience
Faith is unnecessary when resources are limited
Faith is opposed to trusting God’s word
questions.correctAnswer: Faith often begins with scarcity and doubt but can be obedient
questions.explanation: The widow expresses her lack of resources but obeys Elijah’s command (1 Kings 17:12-15); this models the tested faith of Abraham (Romans 4:18-21), the persistent widow (Luke 18:1-8), and Peter stepping out on water (Matthew 14:28-31).

questions.question: What doctrinal truth is affirmed when Elijah prays and God revives the widow’s son?
options: God has power over life and death
Human intercession is ineffective
Only prophets can heal by their own power
Death is irreversible
questions.correctAnswer: God has power over life and death
questions.explanation: Elijah’s prayer and the child’s revival (1 Kings 17:20-22) affirm God's sovereignty over life and death, consistent with John 11:25, Acts 9:40, Romans 6:9, and Revelation 1:18.

questions.question: What does the widow’s declaration about Elijah at the end of the chapter signify about prophetic authority?
options: It confirms that God’s word spoken through His prophet is true
It declares Elijah as a divine being
It shows that prophets are infallible
It emphasizes human wisdom over divine revelation
questions.correctAnswer: It confirms that God’s word spoken through His prophet is true
questions.explanation: The woman acknowledges Elijah as a man of God and the truth of God's word (1 Kings 17:24), affirming the doctrine of prophetic authority as seen in Deuteronomy 18:18-22, Hebrews 1:1-2, 2 Peter 1:20-21, and John 5:39.

questions.question: How does Elijah’s dependence on God’s word rather than political power reflect a key theological principle?
options: Faith in God’s sovereign word over human authority
Reliance on military might for success
Human wisdom as ultimate authority
Political alliances as proof of divine favor
questions.correctAnswer: Faith in God’s sovereign word over human authority
questions.explanation: Elijah acts solely on God’s command (1 Kings 17:1-5), demonstrating faith in divine sovereignty over kingship, aligned with Isaiah 55:11, Proverbs 21:1, Jeremiah 27:5, and Acts 5:29.

questions.question: What does the drying up of the brook Cherith symbolize in the context of God's providence?
options: The need to trust God’s provision in changing circumstances
God’s abandonment of Elijah
Failure of natural resources to sustain life
The end of Elijah’s prophetic ministry
questions.correctAnswer: The need to trust God’s provision in changing circumstances
questions.explanation: When the brook dries up (1 Kings 17:7), Elijah moves on by God's direction (v.8-9), illustrating the believer’s call to trust God's ongoing providence, as seen in Genesis 22:8, Hebrews 11:17-19, Philippians 4:11-13, and Psalm 37:5.

questions.question: In what way does the widow’s question to Elijah about her sin reveal a common human theological struggle?
options: The struggle to reconcile suffering with God’s justice
Complete understanding of God’s plan in suffering
Assurance that suffering is always due to personal sin
Denial of God’s existence in hardship
questions.correctAnswer: The struggle to reconcile suffering with God’s justice
questions.explanation: The widow questions if Elijah has come to remind her of sin and bring death (1 Kings 17:18), reflecting the human difficulty with theodicy, paralleled in Job 1:21-22, Habakkuk 1:13, Romans 8:28, and 2 Corinthians 12:7-10.

questions.question: How does Elijah’s prayer for the widow’s son demonstrate the role of intercessory prayer in salvation history?
options: It shows that God answers faithful prayers for life and restoration
It proves that only prophets can intercede effectively
It suggests prayer can manipulate God’s will
It shows prayer is unnecessary for miracles
questions.correctAnswer: It shows that God answers faithful prayers for life and restoration
questions.explanation: Elijah’s persistent prayer (1 Kings 17:20-21) exemplifies intercession rooted in faith, consistent with Exodus 32:11-14, 1 Timothy 2:1-4, James 5:16, and John 17:20-23.

questions.question: What does God commanding the ravens to feed Elijah teach about God's care for His servants?
options: God provides for His servants in unexpected ways
God only uses human means for provision
God neglects those who serve Him
Provision depends on human planning
questions.correctAnswer: God provides for His servants in unexpected ways
questions.explanation: God’s command to ravens to feed Elijah (1 Kings 17:4-6) highlights divine providence using all creation, consistent with Matthew 6:26, Luke 12:24, Psalm 147:9, and Isaiah 46:4.

questions.question: How does Elijah's obedience to God's command to move to Zarephath reflect biblical teachings about obedience and faith?
options: Obedience often requires trusting God’s guidance despite uncertainty
Obedience is only required when circumstances are clear
Faith can be separated from obedience
Disobedience is justified when provision seems unlikely
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience often requires trusting God’s guidance despite uncertainty
questions.explanation: Elijah obeys God’s instruction to go to an unfamiliar place (1 Kings 17:8-10) demonstrating faith-led obedience, paralleled in Hebrews 11:8, Joshua 1:7, Proverbs 3:5-6, and Psalm 119:60.

questions.question: What messianic theme can be inferred from Elijah’s power to raise the widow’s son from death?
options: Prefiguration of Christ’s power over death and resurrection
Proof that Elijah was the Messiah
Indication that resurrection was common in the Old Testament
Denial of bodily resurrection
questions.correctAnswer: Prefiguration of Christ’s power over death and resurrection
questions.explanation: Elijah raising the dead (1 Kings 17:17-23) prefigures Christ’s resurrection power, consistent with John 11:25-26, Acts 9:36-42, 1 Corinthians 15:20-22, and Romans 6:4.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'the word of the LORD came unto him' in this chapter teach about divine communication?
options: God reveals His will clearly to His prophets
God’s communication is always indirect and mysterious
Prophets rely on human wisdom alone
Divine messages are conveyed only through dreams
questions.correctAnswer: God reveals His will clearly to His prophets
questions.explanation: The repeated phrase (1 Kings 17:2, 8) emphasizes God’s clear revelation to Elijah, consistent with Numbers 12:6, Amos 3:7, Hebrews 1:1-2, and John 14:26.

questions.question: How does Elijah’s status as 'the Tishbite' from Gilead contribute to understanding his prophetic role?
options: It situates Elijah as a man from outside the royal court, emphasizing God’s calling beyond social status
It shows he was a political leader
It means he was a priest by birth
It implies he was a king’s relative
questions.correctAnswer: It situates Elijah as a man from outside the royal court, emphasizing God’s calling beyond social status
questions.explanation: Elijah’s origin (1 Kings 17:1) underscores that God chooses servants regardless of social rank, consistent with Moses (Exodus 3:1), David (1 Samuel 16:1), and Paul (1 Corinthians 1:27-29).

questions.question: What does the miracle of unending meal and oil teach about God’s covenant faithfulness?
options: God faithfully provides according to His covenant promises during times of trial
God’s blessings are conditional on human merit
Provision is always abundant without testing
God’s promises are symbolic, not literal
questions.correctAnswer: God faithfully provides according to His covenant promises during times of trial
questions.explanation: The uninterrupted supply (1 Kings 17:14-16) illustrates God’s covenant faithfulness, paralleling the manna in Exodus 16:35, God’s promise to Abraham (Genesis 12:2-3), Jesus feeding the 5000 (John 6:11), and Philippians 4:19.
